Award.AwardTitle: The Process Of Cultural Interaction In The US Southwest

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Heather Trigg and colleagues from the University of Massachusetts Boston will explore how colonizers adapt to new social and physical environments by investigating the establishment of the Spanish colony of New Mexico during the 17th century. The project examines the way early colonial Spanish households functioned, focusing particularly on how colonists incorporated indigenous Pueblo peoples into household activities, and how they made a living in the Southwest's challenging environment. Spanish colonizers introduced new plants, animals, and agricultural practices into this region, and these and later introductions have had a dramatic effect on the Southwest's landscape. We know little about Spanish household activities during this period or their impacts on the environment. Because all written records held within the colony were destroyed during the Pueblo Rebellion in the late 17th century, archaeology is the primary way that the foundations of Hispanic society in the American Southwest can be understood. The results of this investigation are relevant beyond the region as the Spanish colonization of New Mexico provides a case study for examining the development of relationships between colonizers and indigenous peoples. The research contributes to an understanding of power differentials, cultural pluralism, and the interplay between culture and the environment.

The majority of 17th-century Spanish colonizers lived in rural ranches, making the activities at these locations particularly important. Previous studies of the region's colonization have focused on Pueblo peoples' reactions to this colonization. Thus, Spanish households are an important but underutilized source of information about colonization processes. The research focuses on several questions. What were the colonists' economic strategies? How did they incorporate native peoples' practices and knowledge into these activities? What were the colonists' relationships to the environment? The researchers explore these issues by conducting archaeological excavations and obtaining environmental samples from one of the most important early colonial Spanish sites in New Mexico. The types and distribution of artifacts, such as ceramics, will be used to explore the identity of the people contributing to the household and the types of activities that they engaged. With biological data, such as pollen, researchers will investigate the relationships colonizers had with the environment, focusing particularly on changes resulting from the introduction of plow agriculture and grazing livestock on this marginal environment. The project will provide for the training of graduate students in all aspects of the research. The researchers have developed a partnership with El Rancho de las Golondrinas, a living history museum in Santa Fe, New Mexico that is dedicated to Hispanic history and culture. Information developed through the project will be made available to the general public in the form of exhibits, lectures, and docent training at the museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With funding from the National Science Foundation, this project combined archaeological and environmental analyses to investigate the beginnings of Hispanic society in the American Southwest. In the late 15th and 16th centuries, Spanish colonists moved north from Mexico to found the colony of New Mexico in an area that had been home to indigenous Pueblo peoples for centuries. The project examines the way early colonial Spanish households functioned, focusing particularly on how colonists incorporated indigenous Pueblo peoples into household activities, and how they made a living in the Southwest’s challenging environment.

 

The research explored several questions. What were the colonists’ economic strategies? How did they incorporate native peoples’ practices and knowledge into these activities? What were the colonists’ relationships to the environment? The project used archaeological data from the most complex 17th-century Spanish ranch in New Mexico and pollen analysis from cores at the site and nearby wetlands. Archaeological excavations and analysis of the architecture and the artifacts from this ranch revealed the impact indigenous Pueblo people had on the nature of Hispanic society. Animal bone analysis suggests an emphasis on sheep for both meat and wool, and cultivation of Old World crops, both of which are consistent with Iberian agricultural and pastoral activities. However, the examination of the building materials and methods, the artifacts and plants associated with food production and consumption, and ceramic and stone tools indicate that the Pueblos contributed to the Spanish colonists’ cuisine and cooking methods, to the construction and very nature of their homes, and to functioning of their households and ranches.

 

Spanish colonizers introduced new plants, animals, and agricultural practices into this region, and these and later introductions have had a dramatic effect on the Southwest’s landscape. Pollen analyses suggest population levels of both indigenous Pueblos and Spanish colonizers played a role in the transformation of the landscape. Prior to Spanish arrival, Pueblo peoples had modified their environment. During the early Spanish colonization, local environmental changes surrounding the ranch site were evident, but larger scale environmental impacts appeared to have been somewhat delayed perhaps until the mid-l8th century. It is hypothesized that population levels of both Spanish and Pueblos contributed to environmental change. Pueblo populations were decreasing through the 17th century and it was not until the Spanish population levels, along with their livestock, increased significantly in the 18th century that extensive environmental impact was seen. The results of this project are important for understanding how colonizers in general adapted to new social and physical environments. Environmental impacts were related to the overall scale of populations, not simply occurring with the introduction of Old World livestock. While economic strategies are consistent with colonizers’ agricultural emphasis, there was fundamental negotiation with respect to many aspects of daily life as Pueblo ways of making do were incorporated into the household’s activities.

 

The project has developed a partnership with El Rancho de las Golondrinas, a living history museum in Santa Fe, New Mexico, which is dedicated to Hispanic culture. Information developed through this project has been and will continue to be made available to the general public in the form of exhibits. Tours of the archaeological site were given each year to the museum’s docents. Information was presented that could be incorporated into their work at the museum. There was a public lecture and a more informal session called “ask the archaeologist, ” where the PI talked with and answered questions for the museum’s visitors. The project also afforded opportunities for training to graduate students in all aspects of the research. Graduate students from across the country and from Brazil received practical field and lab experience that helped them obtain employment. Some used data collected during the project in their theses, which has contributed to their research abilities. Research developed during this project has been presented at professional conferences including the Society for American Archaeology. Two MA theses have been completed and four more are underway, and the site materials are currently being used in a PhD dissertation.
